These figures highlight the ongoing global health challenge posed by cancer.

clusters.title: Specific Cancers
clusters.description: In 2022, female breast cancer was a significant global health issue, representing 11.6% of all cancer cases and 6.9% of cancer deaths. It is notably prevalent among women, accounting for nearly one in four cancer cases and one in six cancer deaths. Prostate cancer also posed a major concern, being the second most common cancer among men and the fifth leading cause of cancer death. It was the most frequently diagnosed cancer in 118 countries and led in cancer deaths in 52 countries.

related_facts.fact_group_content: Incidence rates varied from 507.9 per 100,000 in Australia/New Zealand to 97.1 per 100,000 in Western Africa among men.
Incidence rates varied from 410.5 per 100,000 in Australia/New Zealand to 103.3 per 100,000 in South-Central Asia among women.
Mortality rates per 100,000 persons ranged from 68.9 in Central America to 159.6 in Eastern Europe among men.
Mortality rates per 100,000 persons ranged from around 63 in Central America and South-Central Asia to 115.7 in Melanesia among women.
Incidence rates of breast cancer are four times higher in France, Australia/New Zealand, Northern America, and Northern Europe than in South-Central Asia and Middle Africa.
Incidence rates of breast cancer in transitioned countries are 54.1 per 100,000 compared to 30.8 per 100,000 in transitioning countries.
Mortality rates of breast cancer in transitioned countries are 11.3 per 100,000 compared to 15.3 per 100,000 in transitioning countries.
Incidence rates of prostate cancer are almost three times higher in transitioned countries (35.5 per 100,000) than in transitioning countries (12.6 per 100,000).
Mortality rates of prostate cancer are 7.3 per 100,000 in transitioned countries compared to 6.6 per 100,000 in transitioning countries.
Incidence rates of colorectal cancer are three to four times higher in transitioned countries compared to transitioning countries.
The age-standardised rate for all cancers for men and women combined was 196.9 per 100,000 in 2022.
The age-standardised rate for all cancers was 212.6 per 100,000 for men and 186.3 per 100,000 for women.
Incidence rate for all cancers combined was 212.5 per 100,000 in men and 186.2 per 100,000 in women in 2022.
When non-melanoma skin cancer was excluded, the number of cancers globally dropped to 18,741,066.
The rate of cancer when non-melanoma skin cancer was excluded was 186.5 per 100,000.
There were 9,566,825 cases among men when non-melanoma skin cancer was excluded.
There were 9,175,141 cases among women when non-melanoma skin cancer was excluded.
The rate of cancer was 198.6 per 100,000 for men and 178.9 per 100,000 for women when non-melanoma skin cancer was excluded.

clusters.title: Regional Variations
clusters.description: In 2022, the global age-standardised cancer rate was 196.9 per 100,000 for both genders combined. Excluding non-melanoma skin cancer, the global cancer cases numbered 18,741,066. Cancer incidence rates showed significant regional variation, with the highest in Australia/New Zealand and the lowest in Western Africa for men. Transitioned countries reported higher incidence and mortality rates for cancers like breast, colorectal, and prostate compared to transitioning countries.

related_facts.fact_group_content: Approximately 20 million cancer cases were newly diagnosed in 2022.
19,976,499 cases of cancer were diagnosed in 2022.
10,311,610 cases of cancer were diagnosed among men in 2022.
9,664,889 cases of cancer were diagnosed among women in 2022.
China reported more than 1 million cases of cancer in 2022.
Approximately 400,000 children develop cancer each year.
2.3 million new cases of female breast cancer in 2022.
More than 1.9 million new cases of colorectal cancer in 2022.
1.5 million new cases of prostate cancer in 2022.
2.5 million new cases of stomach, liver, and cervix cancers combined in 2022.
Almost 2.5 million new cases of lung cancer in 2022.

clusters.title: Incidence Trends
clusters.description: In 2022, nearly 20 million new cancer cases were diagnosed globally, with a significant number affecting men and women almost equally. China alone reported over 1 million cases, highlighting the widespread impact of cancer. Specific cancer types such as breast, colorectal, and lung cancer had millions of new cases, indicating prevalent health challenges worldwide.

related_facts.fact_group_content: Comprehensive treatment is available in more than 90% of high-income countries.
Comprehensive treatment is available in less than 15% of low-income countries.
Cumulative risk of men developing cancer before age 75 in 2022 ranged from approximately 10% in low HDI settings to over 30% in very high HDI settings.
Cumulative risk of cancer death in men is about 60% higher in high and very high HDI settings compared to low and medium HDI settings (around 12.5% vs. 8%).
Cumulative risk of cancer death in women is higher in low HDI compared with very high HDI settings (8.8% vs. 8.2%).
Cumulative risk of dying from cancer among women in 2022 is highest in Melanesia (11.8%).
Cumulative risk of dying from cancer among women in 2022 is highest in Micronesia/Polynesia (10.5%).
Cumulative risk of dying from cancer among women in 2022 is highest in Eastern Africa (10.7%).
Cumulative risk of dying from cancer among women in 2022 is highest in Southern Africa (10.4%).
Estimated cumulative risks of cancer death are less than 10 in North America (7.9%).
Estimated cumulative risks of cancer death are less than 10 in Southern Europe (8.0%).
Estimated cumulative risks of cancer death are less than 10 in Australia/New Zealand (7.5%).

clusters.title: Treatment Access
clusters.description: Cancer treatment availability and mortality risks vary significantly across different regions and income levels. High-income countries have widespread access to comprehensive cancer treatment, while low-income countries face limited availability. The risk of developing and dying from cancer is notably higher in high Human Development Index (HDI) settings compared to low HDI settings, with significant regional variations in mortality rates among women.

Comprehensive treatment is available in less than 15% of low-income countries

articles.title: Cancer
Global cancer statistics 2022: GLOBOCAN estimates of incidence and mortality worldwide for 36 cancers in 185 countries

all_fact_content: Comprehensive treatment is available in more than 90% of high-income countries.
Comprehensive treatment is available in less than 15% of low-income countries.
Cumulative risk of men developing cancer before age 75 in 2022 ranged from approximately 10% in low HDI settings to over 30% in very high HDI settings.
Cumulative risk of cancer death in men is about 60% higher in high and very high HDI settings compared to low and medium HDI settings (around 12.5% vs. 8%).
Cumulative risk of cancer death in women is higher in low HDI compared with very high HDI settings (8.8% vs. 8.2%).
Cumulative risk of dying from cancer among women in 2022 is highest in Melanesia (11.8%).
Cumulative risk of dying from cancer among women in 2022 is highest in Micronesia/Polynesia (10.5%).
Cumulative risk of dying from cancer among women in 2022 is highest in Eastern Africa (10.7%).
Cumulative risk of dying from cancer among women in 2022 is highest in Southern Africa (10.4%).
Estimated cumulative risks of cancer death are less than 10 in North America (7.9%).
Estimated cumulative risks of cancer death are less than 10 in Southern Europe (8.0%).
Estimated cumulative risks of cancer death are less than 10 in Australia/New Zealand (7.5%).

related_facts.fact_group_content: Around 10 million people died from cancer in 2021.
9.7 million people died from cancer in 2022 worldwide.
10 million deaths in 2020 were attributed to cancer.
Close to 10 million cancer deaths in 2022.
Lung cancer caused an estimated 1.8 million deaths in 2022.
90% of new cases and deaths from cervical cancer occur in low- and middle-income countries.
Approximately one in five men or women develop cancer in a lifetime.
Around one in nine men die from cancer.
Around one in 12 women die from cancer.
The ASDR for cancer decreased by approximately 24.81% in males globally in the past 40 years.
The ASDR for cancer decreased by approximately 24.47% in females globally in the past 40 years.
70% of nearly 10 million cancer-related deaths worldwide in 2020 were in low-and-middle-income countries.

clusters.title: Mortality Disparities
clusters.description: Cancer remains a leading cause of death globally, with around 10 million fatalities annually in recent years. A significant portion of these deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries, highlighting disparities in healthcare access and outcomes. Despite the high mortality, there has been a notable decrease in age-standardized death rates for cancer over the past four decades.

clusters.title: Global Burden
clusters.description: Cancer remains a significant global health challenge, accounting for a substantial portion of deaths and disease burden. In 2021, cancer was responsible for approximately 14.57% of total deaths worldwide. Digestive cancers, particularly colorectal cancer, contribute significantly to cancer mortality, with colorectal cancer ranking third in incidence and second in mortality. The top 10 cancer types account for over 60% of newly diagnosed cases and deaths, highlighting the need for targeted prevention and treatment strategies.
